title: Advanced Topics in Parallel/Distributed Systems
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course covers selected topics in parallel/distributed systems. The detailed contents may be changed from year to year depending on the current development and the teacher specialty.

title: Advanced Topics in Database Systems
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science; and ;Not for students who have taken CSCI5120 and SEEM5010
description: This course will introduce query processing methods that are designed to solve important data management problems in various domains, including spatial databases, uncertain databases, stream databases, and so on. All the techniques discussed have the common features that they (i) have been proven to be highly effective in practice, and (ii) can be easily implemented in real world applications.

title: Topics in Theoretical Computer Science
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course will introduce to students topics in theoretical computer science. The detailed contents may be changed from year to year depending on the current development and available expertise.

title: Advanced Topics in Artificial Intelligence
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science; and ;Exclusion: CSCI6200 or ENGG5189
description: This course will cover selected topics from: advanced pattern recognition, neural networks, expert systems and fuzzy systems, evolutionary computing, learning theory, constraint processing, logic programming, probabilistic reasoning, computer vision, speech processing, and natural language processing.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1. understand audio signal processing procedures and methods of extracting important audio features from audio signals 2. build a simple small vocabulary speech recognition system 3. understand pattern classification methods such as boosting and neural networks 4. know how to perform simple classification problems using boosting and neural networks 5. understand the nature of fuzzy concept in real life 6. familiarize with the fuzzy concepts and fuzzy logic and their application in fuzzy expert system 7. design and implement fuzzy expert system in solving real life problem 8. understand the fundamental principles and the design of genetic algorithm
syllabus: This course will cover selected topics from: advanced pattern recognition, neural networks, expert systems and fuzzy systems, evolutionary computing, learning theory, constraint processing, logic programming, probabilistic reasoning, computer vision, speech processing, and natural language processing.

title: Advanced Topics in Internet Technology
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course will cover advanced topics in Internet technologies. Topics will vary from year to year depending on current research interests. Some typical topics to be discussed will include multimedia streaming, delivery and fault tolerance; content distribution network; peer-to-peer network and services; network economics and incentive; network security and distributed key management; service overlay network, routing and convergence.

title: Image Processing and Computer Vision
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science; and ;Exclusion: CSCI5280 or ENGG5104
description: This course includes fundamental topics in image processing, e.g., image enhancement techniques, color image processing, image segmentation and image compression. In addition, the course also focuses on topics concerning methodologies of recovering 3D information from 2D images. Specifi cally, techniques for camera calibration, stereopsis, motion analysis, pose estimation and structure from motion will be discussed. These techniques will have practical applications to virtual reality, model reconstruction and graphics.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1. understand the mathematics of image formation and modelling of digital cameras, 2. understand how to extract information and features such as point , lines, corners and colour information from images, 3. understand the methods of object tracking 4. understand the methods of exacting 3D information from 2D images, such as stereo vision, pose estimation and model reconstruction from image sequences.
syllabus: This course includes fundamental topics in image processing, e.g., image enhancement techniques, color image processing, image segmentation and image compression. In addition, the course also focuses on topics concerning methodologies of recovering 3D information from 2D images. Specifi cally, techniques for camera calibration, stereopsis, motion analysis, pose estimation and structure from motion will be discussed. These techniques will have practical applications to virtual reality, model reconstruction and graphics.
recommended_readings: 1. Multiple geometry in computer vision, Hartley and Zisserman, Cambridge University Press. 2. Digital image processing, R.C. González, R.E. Woods, Ed.3, Gatesmark Publishing.  3. Learning OpenCV: Computer Vision with the OpenCV Library by Gary Bradski, O'Reilly.

title: Computer Models for E-Business
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course studies the modelling for E-Business, in particular the functional models, customer behaviour models, and resource models. These models will be used in E-Business capacity planning and system performance evaluations. In particular, modelling of contention for software servers and characterizing of E-Business workloads will be included. Other topics cover quantitative analysis of authentication services and payment services.

title: IT Project Management
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science;Exclusion: DSME6730
description: This course covers the key elements of the project management framework related to information technology. Topics include the identification of elements and processes of project management, processes involved in project integration management, project scope management, various tools and techniques used to develop project schedules and resource planning, processes of project quality management, project communications management, risk management, human resource management, and project procurement management. Experts from industry will also be invited to share their experience in the topics.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1. apply project management concepts in initiating, planning, executing and controlling technology projects. 2. strategically identify and manage risks thajavascript:%20submitAction_win0(document.win0,'#ICPanel2');t are associated with a project 3. develop, lead and motivate project teams 4. effectively communicate and work with all project stakeholders 5. use relevant project management software, such as Microsoft Project, to help plan and manage a project.
syllabus: This course covers the key elements of the project management framework related to information technology. Topics include the identification of elements and processes of project management, processes involved in project integration management, project scope management, various tools and techniques used to develop project schedules and resource planning, processes of project quality management, project communications management, risk management, human resource management, and project procurement management. Hughes and M. Cotterell, Software Project Management, 5/e, McGraw-Hill, 2009. 4. J. Meredith and S. Mantel, Jr. Project Management, A Managerial Approach, 8/e, Wiley, 2011.

title: Web Based Graphics & Virtual Reality Systems
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science; and ;Not for students who have taken CSCI5460
description: This course aims to provide students the platform to learn about interactive media and virtual reality with emphasis on their internet applications. Up-to-date interactive media techniques, including modeling, rendering, illumination, texture mapping, animation, and visualization, will be introduced in the first-half of the course. The second-half course will focus on the Web-based VR interfaces which build up the fundamental basis for testing new ideas and alternative solution for the latest VR research, including VR scene modeling, dynamic objects, interactive navigation and sensors, real-time rendering, and diversifed web-based VR applications.

title: Introduction to Computational Finance
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course introduces some basic concepts in computational finance. Topics include risk and return, modern portfolio theory, calculating the effi cient frontier, multiple factor models, various models for portfolio optimization, utility functions and evaluation of portfolio performance.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to  1. understand the relationship between risks and returns, their measurements and relevance in portfolio management 2. have a basic understanding of modern portfolio theory 3. be able to apply computational techniques to model asset allocation 4. be able to evaluate the performance of portfolios
syllabus: This course introduces some basic concepts in computational finance. Topics include risk and return, modern portfolio theory, calculating the effi cient frontier, multiple factor models, various models for portfolio optimization, utility functions and evaluation of portfolio performance.

John Wiley and Sons, 2007 ISBN: 0470050829.  • An Elementary Introduction to Mathematical Finance Options and other Topics (2nd Edition), by Sheldon M. Ross, Cambridge University Press.

title: Seminar
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: A series of 12 seminars on current topics in computer science to be presented by experts from academia or industry.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the knowledge of various current topics in computer science in academia or industry.
syllabus: A series of 12 seminars on current topics in computer science to be presented by experts from academia or industry.

title: Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science;Not for students who have taken CSCI5180 or ENGG5103
description: This course introduces the techniques used in data mining. Topics include clustering, classification, estimation, forecasting, statistical analysis and visualization. Data Mining provides useful tools for the analysis and visualization. Data Mining provides useful tools for the analysis, understanding and extraction of useful information from huge databases. Applications range from business, finance, medicine and engineering.
outcome: After successful completion of this course, students should be able  • to identify the objectives of the real world data mining problems,  • to select and apply the right techniques to solve these problems,  • to systematically evaluate the results obtained.
syllabus: This course introduces the techniques used in data mining. Topics include clustering, classification, estimation, forecasting, statistical analysis and visualization. Data Mining provides useful tools for the analysis and visualization. Data Mining provides useful tools for the analysis, understanding and extraction of useful information from huge databases. Applications range from business, finance, medicine and engineering.
recommended_readings: Pang-Ning Tan, Michael Steinbach, and Vipin Kumar. Introduction to Data Mining. Jiawei Han, Micheline Kamber, and Jian Pei. Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques.  Mohammed J. Zaki, and Wagner Meira Jr. Data Mining and Analysis: Fundamental Concepts and Algorithms.

title: Computer and Network Security
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science; and ;Not for students who have taken CSCI5470 or IERG5240 or ENGG5105 or ENGG5383
description: Issues of computer and network security. Weaknesses of network protocols. Security protocols. Firewalls. Computer viruses. System security threats. Applications of Cryptography.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1.Identify software weakness that are vulnerable to various attacks 2.Analyze network logs to identify network-related attacks based on IP spoofing, TCP exploit, arp-spoofing, and man-in-the-middle attacks etc. 3.Set up a firewall properly 4.Protect information based on encryptions and authentications 5.Aware the potential security threats based on some advanced cryptoanalysis techniques
syllabus: Issues of computer and network security. Weaknesses of network protocols. Security protocols. Firewalls. Computer viruses. System security threats. Applications of Cryptography.
recommended_readings: 1. W. Stallings, Cryptography and Network Security: Principles and Practice, 7th ed. Pearson, 2016. 2. E. Skoudis and T. Liston, Counter Hack Reloaded: A Step-by-Step Guide to Computer Attacks and Effective Defenses, 2nd ed. Prentice Hall, 2006. 3. R. Russell, Hack Proofing Your Network: Internet Tradecraft, 2nd ed.2000. 4. A. One, "Smashing the Stack for Fun and Profit", Phrack, vol. 7, no.49, 1996. 5. B. Claerhout, "A short overview of IP spoofing: Part I", 1996. 6. Y. Volobuev, "Playing redir games with ARP and ICMP", 1997.

title: Computer Game Software Production
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course focuses on the programming issues in computer gaming software production, discusses the process in developing a game application and analyzes various considerations in technologies used. The main emphasis is on the real time performance requirement in computer game development. Indoor/outdoor rendering, networking, artificial intelligence, physics as well as the game design issues would be introduced.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1. Understand and develop computer graphics rendering programs 2. Build a typical game level using corresponding tools 3. Construct the AI of the game to make the game more challenging, 4. Appreciate the complexity involved in modern computer game software
syllabus: This course focuses on the programming issues in computer gaming software production, discusses the process in developing a game application and analyzes various considerations in technologies used. The main emphasis is on the real time performance requirement in computer game development. Indoor/outdoor rendering, networking, artificial intelligence, physics as well as the game design issues would be introduced.
recommended_readings: 1. Game Programming Gems series http://www.gameprogramminggems.com/  2. Daniel S. Dalmau “Core Techniques and Algorithms in Game Programming”, New Riders Publishing 2004.  3. Alan Watt & Fabio Policarpo “3D Games Real-time Rendering and Software Technology Vol. 1 & 2”, Addison-Wesley 2001.  4. Andrew Rollings & Ernest Adams “Andrew Rollings & Ernest Adams on Game Design”, New Riders Publishing 2003.

title: Decision Analysis & Game Theory
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science; Not for students who have taken CSCI5350
description: This course introduces decision theory and game theory used in computer science, in particular, artificial intelligence and multiagent systems. Topics include utility theory, decisions under risk, decisions under uncertainty, social choices, strategic games and Nash equilibrium, extensive games and subgame perfect equilibrium, repeated games and folk theorems, and applications in computer science.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1. Model and analyse problems using utility theory 2. Understand the issues of decisions under risk and decisions under uncertainty 3. Understand the issues of social choices 4. Model and analyse problems using strategic games and Nash equilibrium, extensive games and subgame perfect equilibrium, repeated games and folk theorems.
syllabus: This course introduces decision theory and game theory used in computer science, in particular, artificial intelligence and multiagent systems. Topics include utility theory, decisions under risk, decisions under uncertainty, social choices, strategic games and Nash equilibrium, extensive games and subgame perfect equilibrium, repeated games and folk theorems, and applications in computer science.
recommended_readings: M. J. Osborne and A. Rubinstein, 1994. A Course in Game Theory. The MIT Press.

title: IT Entrepreneurship and Marketing
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course equips students with the skills on how to create, launch and run an IT business and to develop a coherent marketing strategy. The key topics include entrepreneur characteristics, identifying market opportunity, IT product/service management, business planning, formation of a new IT venture, financing, market segmentation, positioning, pricing, promotion, distribution and channel management.
outcome: After completing this course, the students will be able to: 1. understand what it takes to be a successful IT entrepreneur; 2. be encouraged to be more market-oriented when developing IT products/services in their studies and workplaces; 3. know how to apply major marketing concepts to the task of profitably winning business from targeted customers; 4. gain hands-on experiences in identifying business opportunities and developing business and marketing plan through case studies and course projects.
syllabus: This course equips students with the skills on how to create, launch and run an IT business and to develop a coherent marketing strategy. The key topics include entrepreneur characteristics, identifying market opportunity, IT product/service management, business planning, formation of a new IT venture, financing, market segmentation, positioning, pricing, promotion, distribution and channel management.
recommended_readings: 1. W.D. Bygrave and A. Zacharakis. Entrepreneurship, Wiley & Sons, 2007.  2. R.C. Dorf and T.H. Byers. Technology Ventures from Idea to Enterprise, McGraw-Hill, 2005. 3. J.P. Peter and J.H. Donnelly, Jr. A Preface to Marketing Management, 12/e, McGraw-Hill/Irwin, 2010.  4. A. Ryans, R. More, D. Barclay and T. Deutscher. Winning Market Leadership: Strategic Market Planning for Technology-Driven Businesses, Wiley, 1999. 5. D.J. Coover. Entrepreneurship & Marketing in the 21st Century: From Student to CEO in One Semester, AIM Institute, 2008. 6. K. Blois (editor). The Oxford Textbook of Marketing, Oxford University Press, 2001. 7. L. Pinson. Anatomy of a Business Plan: The Step-by-Step Guide to Building a Business and Securing Your Company's Future, 7/e, 2008.

title: Social Computing
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course introduces recent developments in the emerging field of social computing, which investigates the information processing of social signals that arise from the interactions among entities through social media technologiessuch as social networking sites, blogs, SMS, mails, virtual communities, multimedia sharing sites, mobile devices, etc. Topics include, but not limited to, social network theories, link analysis, learning to rank, graph algorithms, question and answering, recommender systems, etc. The students should have some knowledge in the area of machine learning, data mining, or other related fields.

title: Network Science
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course introduces network science as an emerging discipline that studies the networks for revelation of organised knowledge in them, so that network behaviour and various phenomena can be predicted. Topics include the introduction of various networks, such as regular networks, random networks, small-world networks and scale-free networks. The emergence of networks will be discussed. Then various important issues in networks such as epidemics, synchrony, influence network, vulnerability, NetGain and biology are discussed.

title: Advanced Topics in Cloud Computing
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course covers advanced topics in cloud computing. Topics will include new problems proposed in each year. Some topics to be discussed include: cloud computing models (e.g., SaaS, PaaS, IaaS); distributed and parallel data processing (e.g. MapReduce, Hadoop); data storage (cloud storage architectures, data centers, data deduplication); case studies of real-world cloud services (e.g. Amazon EC2, Windows Azure).

title: Mobile Apps Design and Implementation
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course aims at introducing principles involved in mobile application design and implementation. Topics include: development and deployment process for mobile applications, graphical user interface design, mobile file systems, networking and energy saving consideration. Location & map based application will be studied specifically. Finally, the marketing plan as well as various revenue models in mobile application will also be considered.

title: Web Search and Text Analysis
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science
description: This course will cover the modeling and algorithmic aspects of web search engines. Topics include tf-idf scoring, page rank, inverted index, trie, suffix tree, string B-tree, q-gram, error-tolerant keyword search, deep web, and so on. On completion, students are expected to have acquired solid understanding on fundamental text retrieval and link analysis.

title: Big Data Technology and Applications
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science; Not for students who have taken CCSI5510 or ENGG5108
description: This course aims at teaching students the state-of-the-art big data technology, including techniques, software, applications, and perspectives with massive data. The class will cover, but not be limited to, the following topics: advanced techniques in distributed file systems such as Google File System, Hadoop Distributed File System, and map-reduce technology; similarity search techniques for big data such as minhash, locality-sensitive hashing; specialized processing and algorithms for data streams; big data search and query technology; recommendation systems for Web applications. The applications may involve business applications such as online marketing, computational advertising, location-based services, social networks, recommender systems, healthcare services.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1. Understand the key issues on big data and the associated applications in intelligent business and scientific computing. 2. Acquire fundamental enabling techniques and scalable algorithms in big data technology. 3. Interpret business models and scientific computing paradigms, and apply big data technology. 4. Achieve adequate perspectives of big data technology in modern applications.
syllabus: This course aims at teaching students the state-of-the-art big data technology, including techniques, software, applications, and perspectives with massive data. The class will cover, but not be limited to, the following topics: advanced techniques in distributed file systems such as Google File System, Hadoop Distributed File System, and map-reduce technology; similarity search techniques for big data such as minhash, locality-sensitive hashing; specialized processing and algorithms for data streams; big data search and query technology; recommendation systems for Web applications. The applications may involve business applications such as online marketing, computational advertising, location-based services, social networks, recommender systems, healthcare services.
recommended_readings: 1. (textbook): Anand Rajaraman and Jeffrey David Ullman, Mining of Massive Datasets, Cambridge University Press, 2011. 2. Frank J. Ohlhorst. Big Data Analytics: Turning Big Data into Big Money. Wiley. 2012. 3. Toby Segar. Programming Collective Intelligence: Building Smart Web 2.0 Applications. O'Reilly Media, 2007.

title: Efficient Computing of Deep Neural Networks
requirements: For students in MSc Computer Science;Not for students who have taken CENG5030 or ELEG5491
description: The high computational demands of deep neural networks (DNNs) coupled with their pervasiveness across both cloud and IoT platforms have led to a rise in specialized hardware and software techniques to accelerate DNN executions. This course will present techniques that enable efficient applications and computing of DNNs. The course will start with an overview of DNNs, and then will introduce various frameworks and architectures that support DNNs, as well as the implementations and optimizations on some particular computing platforms.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to1. Comprehend the mechanisms, applications, and limitations of techniques commonly used in training and inference of deep neural network algorithms;2. Utilize proper engineering techniques for deep neural network models;3. Formulate hypotheses and conduct experiments employing these techniques;4. Analyse experimental results obtained by these techniques and one’s own practices and derive the conclusions that are supported or not supported by one’s data;5. Propose new engineering approaches and techniques to further enhance deep neural network training and inference execution.
syllabus: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired1. knowledge in deep neural network (DNN) architecture and structures;2. knowledge in DNN training and inference procedures and algorithms;3. knowledge in efficient computing of DNN training and inference.
required_readings: 1. I. Goodfellow et al., “Deep Learning”, 2016.2. E. Wang et al., “Deep Neural Network Approximation for Custom Hardware: Where We've Been, Where We're Going”, 2019.3. K. Guo et al. “A Survey of FPGA-based Neural Network Inference Accelerators”, 2019.4. Q. Zhang et al. “Recent advances in convolutional neural network acceleration”, 2019.
